Yes, I have the text for chapter 11 of the original book. Here it is:

CHAPTER ELEVEN
Stress and Back Pain
From Chris

The day I sat down to edit this chapter for the last time, there was an obituary in the New York Times for John E. Sarno, MD, who “wrote the book” (Healing Back Pain) on what he claimed (without support, I’m afraid) were the psychological origins of back pain. As the Times put it, he was “revered by some as a saint and dismissed by others as a quack.” That is still roughly the state of his reputation today: some people believe him, some don’t.

What he said was that many (most?) cases of chronic back pain were caused by repressed anger. That’s right: anger. You were angry at your boss, your spouse, your kids, or yourself, and you couldn’t admit it to yourself. So you bottled it up and the stress of that repressed anger somehow “suffocated” your oxygen-starved back muscles, and your back “went out.” The solution was to admit the anger and other “repressed feelings,” forgive the people involved (including yourself), and try to “express” the feelings more openly.

Does that make sense? Do you find that plausible?

I have no idea. It’s a fascinating idea, and the testimonials on Sarno’s web site are, well, impressive. But then, so are the testimonials on the web sites of other self-help gurus. I do know that a very wise person (a man who has helped me with many of my personal demons over the years) has long believed that a good deal of back pain is psychologically induced. And I have also read that back pain is one of the leading causes of doctor visits in the United States, and that many (most?) of the expensive back operations and other treatments have no long-lasting benefit.

So here is my contribution to the debate. I have an old friend, a retired psychoanalyst, who tells me that one of his patients was a man who had had multiple back operations, and his back still hurt all the time. So the analyst asked him to try this: every time he felt back pain coming on, he was to write down what he was thinking and feeling at that moment. After a few weeks of this, the patient came back to the analyst and said: “You know what? My back doesn’t hurt anymore.”

Can this be true? I have no idea. But it is worth noting that the biofeedback folks, who are not given to frivolous claims, use “stress management” techniques to alleviate back pain. And there is a ton of literature on the close relationship between stress and back pain.

It is certainly true that stress affects us all in many ways. Stress causes or exacerbates heart disease, diabetes, multiple sclerosis, cancer, infections, and a host of other maladies. But the relationship between stress and pain is not always easy to understand. I personally have found that back pain is a great stress barometer. If I am upset about something (which is most of the time, unfortunately), my back muscles tense up and, sometimes, spasm. Conversely, when I am “relaxed,” my back feels fine. I’m sure this is true of many people.

It is also true that the stress-related symptoms of back pain can be treated. It seems to me that, at a minimum, we can avoid making our back pain worse by avoiding stress as much as possible (duh), meditating or doing something similar (yoga is wonderful for this), and focusing hard on the moment.
